awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChEM: Electron Transfer Mechanisms in Metal Organic Framework Thin Films
awd_abstract_narration:
In this CAREER project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division and the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research, Professor Amanda Morris of the Department of Chemistry at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University is exploring the optical and electronic properties of metal organic framework thin films arrays. The goal of the project is to learn how to control these properties and aid in the development of artificial photosynthetic assemblies capable of converting solar energy into chemical fuels for long-term storage and use. The project addresses critical, present-day environmental and energy technology challenges at the interface of many scientific disciplines (chemistry, physics, and biology). At the high school level, four laboratory modules are being developed to complement the Virginia Standards of Learning through the full sequence and scope of the high school science program. These modules provide laboratory experiences with real-world applications to a diverse population of students and afford the opportunity for teachers to apply the curriculum to one of today's most active research fields. This component feeds into a new undergraduate course entitled "Energy Sources of the Future," which promotes undergraduate research experiences, emphasizes the cross-disciplinary nature of energy science, and involves literature studies, guest lectures, and laboratory experiments.

Metal organic frameworks (MOF) are a class of solid-state inorganic-organic hybrid materials that combine the stability of heterogeneous materials with the synthetic diversity of molecular complexes. The research aims to discover the relationship between the molecular and three-dimensional structure of metal organic frameworks and observed electron transport properties. In this project, a series of systematically varied metal organic framework structures are explored to: (1) Elucidate the mechanism of electrochemical electron transport through MOF thin films; (2) Determine the contributions of electronic and ionic diffusion to apparent ambipolar diffusion coefficients; (3) Uncover the guiding principles to efficient photo-induced charge transport in MOF arrays. These objectives are accomplished through the correlation of structure, as determined by crystallography, to efficiency and mechanism, as measured by electrochemistry and pulsed-laser spectroscopy.  As part of the proposal, a hands-on educational program capitalizes on the breadth and appeal of the research area to educate future scientists and teachers at the high school level

por.por_cntn:
Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a promising platform for electrocatalysis, (photo)electrochemical energy storage, and electrochemical (chemiresistive) sensing. Fundamental to these applications is the process of charge transport, i.e., the motion of electrons through molecular orbitals (or bands) coupled to the motion of counter-balancing ions. The Morris group was the first to propose and apply a redox hopping mechanistic analysis to charge transport in MOFs. Our recent efforts expanding on this seminal work have enabled the quantification of the rates of electron and ion motion independently to determine the impact molecular self-exchange rates and MOF architecture have on charge transport. The determination of the mechanism was quite powerful as it enabled us to provide design rules to increase the charge transport rates. The design rules are as follows:

1. Choose redox active units with small reorganization energies upon oxidation and reduction. The rate of ergoneutral electron (or hole) motion is dictated by the reorganization, both internal - changes in bond lengths and angles, and external - solvent rearrangement, that occurs upon self-exchange. Thus, the greater the degree of reorganization, the slower the rate.

2. Minimize the distance between redox active units. Marcus theory reveals that the rate of outer-sphere electron transfer is dependent upon the distance between the donor and acceptor species. Species that are < 10 Angstroms apart will exhibit larger orbital overlap than those > 10 Angstroms.

3. Keep the ion size small, pore size large, and provide a direct path for diffusion. The motion of the ions during the process is through the confined pore space of the MOF. Diffusion in MOFs is a complicating factor for many applications from gas transport to the topic of interest, electrochemistry. 

We applied these design rules to demonstrate efficient biomass conversion and bio-sensing applications. Additionally, we perfected the synthesis of pure-phase porphyrin-containing MOFs, including control over the ratio of MOF particle length to width - or the aspect ratio, opening up applications in water purification, optics, and polymer composites.

As the major component of K-12 and under-represented group outreach, I established a partnership with Wonder Universe, A Children's Museum to educate local K-5 students about photosynthesis. Together, we conceptualized an interactive museum exhibit that will educate students through the power of play. The students toss bean bags at a spinning board that features water, carbon dioxide, and light - the photosynthetic starting materials. When the student successfully uses the bean bags to turn one of each tile, they can run up the playing board and hit a button which causes the sun, mounted above the exhibit, to shine. The exhibit was installed in December of 2020. Educational materials to accompany the exhibit were developed for classroom excursions in collaboration with a local high school biology teacher. They include additional experiments to do at home, so learning will continue beyond the walls of the museum and classroom. In addition to developing the exhibit, I have filmed chemistry demonstration videos for Wonder Universe's "Kitchen Chemistry" series that was developed during the pandemic lockdown. The experiments were conducted by my General Chemistry II students. Finally, apart from my work with Wonder Universe, I have conducted a series of experiments around global climate change and artificial energy sources for Virginia Tech's Black College Institute, the Junior ROTC program, the Virginia Science Museum, Virginia Tech's College of Science "Ask an Expert" series, and Virginia Tech's Explore Science Camp.

Over the project period, we published 10 papers. Our primary research articles appeared in the Journal of the American Chemical Society, Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters, Chemical Communications (two invited), Inorganic Chemistry (three), and Dalton Transactions. I was invited to present the work at four American Chemical Society Meetings, one Canadian Chemistry Conference, and one Gordon Research Conference (Inorganic Reaction Mechanisms). I was the co-organizer of a symposium for the Inorganic Division of the American Chemical Society entitled "Fundamentals of Metal Organic Framework Catalysis". Students who were directly supported by the grant presented at National American Chemical Society Meetings (six students - including two undergraduates), Southeastern Regional American Chemical Society Meetings (two students), and the Inter-American Photochemical Society (this student was awarded the 3rd place poster award).
